content.p: Suppose that {{product1}} sells for ${{c1}} a unit and requires {{a11}} units of {{material1}}, {{a21}} units of {{material2}}, {{a31}} units of {{material3}}, and {{a41}} units of {{material4}}. {{product2}} sells for ${{c2}} a unit and requires {{a12}} units of {{material1}}, {{a22}} units of {{material2}}, {{a32}} units of {{material3}}, and {{a42}} units of {{material4}}. {{product3}} sells for ${{c3}} a unit and requires {{a13}} units of {{material1}}, {{a23}} units of {{material2}}, {{a33}} units of {{material3}}, and {{a43}} units of {{material4}}. {{product4}} sells for ${{c4}} a unit and requires {{a14}} units of {{material1}}, {{a24}} units of {{material2}}, {{a34}} units of {{material3}}, and {{a44}} units of {{material4}}. There are {{b1}} units of {{material1}}, {{b2}} units of {{material2}}, {{b3}} units of {{material3}}, {{b4}} units of {{material4}}. We wish to maximize revenue. For each material, if one were to recieve one more unit of each material, how would that change the optimal revenue?
